Description: Terracotta reclining ithyphallic Harpocrates figure. A child is reclining on a plain rectangular plinth, modelled in the round, his legs extended to his right, the left leg on the ground, the right knee raised. He rests his right arm on his large phallus, the glans lies behind his left elbow. Solid; two-piece mould. White coating remains, over which the plinth was painted blue and the skin red. Light brown clay with sparse mica inclusions.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Ashmolean Museum, Oxford. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

A number of similar pieces from Naukratis of this type (Oxford, Ashmolean Museum AN1896-1908-E.3719; British Museum GR1973,0501.19, GR1973,0501.20, GR1973,0501.36) and parallels strangling a goose (British Museum GR1973,0501.24, Brussels, Musées Royaux d’Art et d’Histoire A.1833) have been found. Similar unprovenanced parallels are dated end of fourth, beginning of third century BC (Fischer 1994, no. 19) and are known from Ptolemaic Memphis (Petrie Museum UC48467, UC48376). Similar reclining Harpocrates figures were made of faience, found in a third century BC context at Athribis (Szymańska 1999b, 73, fig. 2) and also found at Naukratis (British museum GR1886,0401.1495) and Karnak (Masson pers. com). Fischer, J. 1994, Griechisch-römische Terrakotten aus Ägypten. Die Sammlungen Sieglin und Schreiber, Dresden, Leipzig, Stuttgart, Tübingen, Tübinger Studien zur Archäologie und Kunstgeschichte 14, Tübingen. Szymańska, H. 1999, in Grimal, N. (ed.) Tell-Edfou, soixante ans après, Actes du colloque franco- polonais, Le Caire, 15 octobre 1996, Cairo.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (DC.224) (Phase 3)
